awd_titl_txt: ELT Collaborative Research: Causes and effects of the Permian-Triassic biotic crisis inferred from continental margin sections and modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
The end-Permian mass extinction (EPME) was the most severe biotic crisis in the past 540 million years of Earth history. This project aims to identify the timing, nature, and causes of paleoenvironmental stresses leading up to and following the EPME, focusing on well-exposed sedimentary successions exposed in eastern Australia, and supported by climate modelling studies. The project will integrate data from several disciplines to explore the hypotheses that a) the EPME was part of a longer-term crisis that followed earlier events in the Middle-Late Permian, b) the crisis was not manifested simultaneously across the paleolatitudes, and c) continental ecosystems responded to the crisis in different ways than marine ecosystems. Students will be trained and public displays will be developed at the University of Nebraska State Museum.

The EPME has gained relevance as an example of an end-member ecological catastrophe that could potentially be replicated in the future. Coastal settings are among the most densely populated today, yet previous studies of the EPME have focused largely on oceanic and continental interior records. In investigating deposits that accumulated along ~2000 km of coastline spanning temperate to polar latitudes, the proposed project will improve understanding of the response of continental margins to rapid environmental change. This work will potentially transform understanding of the timeframes, driving mechanisms, global variability, and ultimate causes of the most severe global ecologic crisis of the Phanerozoic.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project, new sedimentological, paleobotanical, and geochemical data from stratigraphically complete sections in eastern Australia that represent a high-latitude continental margin during the Permian-Triassic transition have been integrated with climate model results.  The end-Permian is marked by the largest mass extinction of the geological record, which might have occurred as a result of or in conjunction with massive Siberian Trap volcanism and methane emissions from intrusions into the West Siberian Coal Basin.  The end-Permian ocean is characterized by acidification and widespread anoxic conditions and thus could serve as an analog for future climate change and mass extinctions.  

Here we use high-precision dating of zircons from continental sequences of the Sydney Basin, Australia, to show that the collapse of the austral Permian Glossopteris flora occurred prior to 252.3 Ma (~370 kyrs before the main marine extinction). Rapid climate change was a major contributor to the end-Permian extinction (EPE). Although well constrained for the marine realm, relatively few records document the pace, nature, and magnitude of climate change across the EPE in terrestrial environments. We generated proxy records for chemical weathering and land surface temperature from continental margin deposits of the high-latitude southeastern margin of Gondwana. Paleoclimate modeling suggests a moderate shift to warmer summer temperatures and amplified seasonality in temperature across the EPE in this region, and warmer and wetter conditions for all seasons in the Early Triassic. 

Lithological proxy data were compiled for the Upper Permian and Lower Triassic and compared with climate sensitivity simulations. The climate simulation using a very high radiative forcing (corresponding to 12.7 times the preindustrial atmospheric CO2 level) together with changes in cloud optical depth produces the best fit to the hothouse climate of the Early Triassic as inferred from the sedimentary record.

Phytogeographical patterns and reconstructed biomes are in reasonable agreement with the biomes inferred from time-slice climate simulations across the PTB.  Consideration of higher model resolution and interactive paleo-vegetation dynamics in the climate model would likely further reduce model-data biases. For this purpose, new high-resolution boundary conditions for climate models have been developed which can be utilized for future climate intercomparison projects.

This project contributed to an improved understanding of short-term and long-term impacts of anthropogenic CO2emissions, potentially resulting in a transition into a hothouse climate. The study successfully tested earth system models under extreme climate conditions and provided training in the STEM discipline and in handling big data for diverse undergraduate and graduate students, and stimulated interest in science for high school students from underrepresented groups through research projects and field excursions. 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2022
Modified by: Cornelia Winguth
